channel.title: PayPal Covering Intangibles
channel.description:
PayPal is updating their buyer protection to cover intangibles (services, digital goods, etc). While this is definitely a good thing for the buyer, it also benefits us in the RSPS world. As a seller, disputes are going to be a lot easier to win provided you have proper logs to show they actually received the goods.
https://www.paypal.com/webapps/mpp/brc/buyer-protection

item.title: PayPal Covering Intangibles
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

t4:

don’t do reversible transactions with kids

Read full topic

item.title: PayPal Covering Intangibles
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

There was that one time I bought RS monies and ching ching never delivered and won the paypal dispute with the statement “it was for intangible goods”.

Read full topic

item.title: PayPal Covering Intangibles
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:17, topic:552092”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=671010.msg4487210#msg4487210 date=1434915159]

What kind of logs could you possibly have that couldn’t be forged?

MySQL databases can be edited, raw text files can be edited, etc.
I don’t see you having any credible information, aside from an image of the user logged on their account with the item(s), that paypal would even look at.
And at that point, its your word against theirs, and paypal likes to side with the buyer; unless it’s a trusted seller and even then they tend to side with the buyer.

Why would you, the seller, need to edit the logs? If they truly never received their items, then you would refund it anyways. If they did receive them, theres no reason to edit the logs as they would already be in your favor.
[/quote]

lol???

[ol][li]Receive payment for item[/li]
[li]Don’t provide item[/li]
[li]Edit logs to show that you provided items[/li]
[li]???[/li]
[li]PROFIT!!![/li][/ol]

[/quote]

It is a virtual world where you control everything… It doesn’t cost you anything to create/give the item. You aren’t making any more or less profit by scamming your players. All you are doing is hurting your reputation.

Read full topic

item.title: PayPal Covering Intangibles
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

If it is an item you as a game owner sold the buyer, take the item back from them/ban them for fraud.

Read full topic

item.title: PayPal Covering Intangibles
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:11, topic:552092”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=671010.msg4487188#msg4487188 date=1434911532]
What kind of logs could you possibly have that couldn’t be forged?

MySQL databases can be edited, raw text files can be edited, etc.
I don’t see you having any credible information, aside from an image of the user logged on their account with the item(s), that paypal would even look at.
And at that point, its your word against theirs, and paypal likes to side with the buyer; unless it’s a trusted seller and even then they tend to side with the buyer.
[/quote]
Why would you, the seller, need to edit the logs? If they truly never received their items, then you would refund it anyways. If they did receive them, theres no reason to edit the logs as they would already be in your favor.[/quote]

lol???

[ol][li]Receive payment for item[/li]
[li]Don’t provide item[/li]
[li]Edit logs to show that you provided items[/li]
[li]???[/li]
[li]PROFIT!!![/li][/ol]

Read full topic

item.title: PayPal Covering Intangibles
item.dc:creator: @EcoPS_GM EcoPS GM
item.description:
@EcoPS_GM wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:12, topic:552092”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=671010.msg4487210#msg4487210 date=1434915159]

What kind of logs could you possibly have that couldn’t be forged?

MySQL databases can be edited, raw text files can be edited, etc.
I don’t see you having any credible information, aside from an image of the user logged on their account with the item(s), that paypal would even look at.
And at that point, its your word against theirs, and paypal likes to side with the buyer; unless it’s a trusted seller and even then they tend to side with the buyer.

Why would you, the seller, need to edit the logs? If they truly never received their items, then you would refund it anyways. If they did receive them, theres no reason to edit the logs as they would already be in your favor.
[/quote]
The point is that the data can be manipulated, and paypal knows that.
So even if you supply the logs and etc… Paypal could think you forged it to say what it does.[/quote]
ToS.

Read full topic

item.title: PayPal Covering Intangibles
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

currency is just something we all agree has value, a piece of paper or non-precious metal coin does not hold much value on its own. the same thing could be said about bitcoin.

item.title: PayPal Covering Intangibles
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:9, topic:552092”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=671010.msg4487187#msg4487187 date=1434911499]

you could just integrate bitcoin and never have to worry about a dispute ever.

Why is that the case?
[/quote]you cant dispute on bitcoin transfers fudgewit (assuming you arent using some weird vendor)[/quote]
So if something goes wrong you’re fucked.

Read full topic

item.title: PayPal Covering Intangibles
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:11, topic:552092”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=671010.msg4487188#msg4487188 date=1434911532]
What kind of logs could you possibly have that couldn’t be forged?

MySQL databases can be edited, raw text files can be edited, etc.
I don’t see you having any credible information, aside from an image of the user logged on their account with the item(s), that paypal would even look at.
And at that point, its your word against theirs, and paypal likes to side with the buyer; unless it’s a trusted seller and even then they tend to side with the buyer.
[/quote]
Why would you, the seller, need to edit the logs? If they truly never received their items, then you would refund it anyways. If they did receive them, theres no reason to edit the logs as they would already be in your favor.[/quote]
The point is that the data can be manipulated, and paypal knows that.
So even if you supply the logs and etc… Paypal could think you forged it to say what it does.

Read full topic

item.title: PayPal Covering Intangibles
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:8, topic:552092”]What kind of logs could you possibly have that couldn’t be forged?

MySQL databases can be edited, raw text files can be edited, etc.
I don’t see you having any credible information, aside from an image of the user logged on their account with the item(s), that paypal would even look at.
And at that point, its your word against theirs, and paypal likes to side with the buyer; unless it’s a trusted seller and even then they tend to side with the buyer.[/quote]
Why would you, the seller, need to edit the logs? If they truly never received their items, then you would refund it anyways. If they did receive them, theres no reason to edit the logs as they would already be in your favor.
